Fields.DialogueText: Good work, Kanchou! You're getting better at this.
Thanks, Hiei. I really appreciate you taking the time to teach me what you know.
You are helping me, as well, in the process. I am always learning more about how to fight, you know.
Heh, that's you all right.
Even so, I feel that we need to take things in a different direction.
What do you mean?
We have been testing our individual strengths by fighting against each other. We need to work on fighting as a team.
That's going to be a little trickier, but I see your point. So what's the next step, then?
I am not entirely sure. I wanted to get your opinion on the matter.

Fields.MenuText: We could try to recruit others so we can have team battles between groups.
Let's try running through obstacle courses together.
Maybe just interacting more will help us understand each other better.

Fields.DialogueText: That would work very well. This could let us expand the teaching to the larger fleet.
Good idea. That would be an excellent test of our capabilities, and of our bond.
I suppose that's our best option at this point. Best to think this through.
So, shall we get started?
Yes, let us –
*ALARM*
On second thought, I forgot that there is another way for us to practice teamwork.
We had better do our best, then. Let's go!
@BATTLE
Sort of like a double date... I mean, double dare, with the challenge and all.
Can't say I'll like the ordeal, but I'm looking forward to it.
Plus, I think we're not just growing stronger every day – we're also growing closer.
Oh, Kanchou?
Yes, Hiei?
I made a little something that I would like you to try.
It looks great! What is it?
Kaiseki ryori, a Kyoto classic, with multiple courses should you feel the need.
Thanks, but you didn't need to do all of this for me.
Well, I wanted to use this as an exercise for strengthening my skills outside of battle. And... I thought you might like it.
Judging from the sample I've taken, you made a good choice. But aren't you going to have some yourself?
Me? No, that would be improper. It is not my habit to indulge in earthly delights.

Fields.MenuText: If the food is to be mine, then it is my right to share it with you, is it not?
I was hoping that we could talk with each other as we dine.
You deserve to have at least some of the meal that you put so much effort into.

Fields.DialogueText: It is. And it would be discourteous of me to refuse the invitation once it is given.
That... would be nice. I would enjoy sharing a meal with you.
Well... okay, just this once.
So? How was it?
Pretty decent.
Humble as always, huh? Well, thanks for sharing the meal with me, and for making it to begin with.
You're welcome. I wanted to reward you for all of your hard work in our training.
No, I should be thanking you for letting me study and grow with you.
Now who's being the humble one, eh?
*ALARM*
More Morganas, of course. Are you up for this, Hiei?
Of course. I'm all fueled up now, so I'm ready to fry those yokai and send them to the Enma.
@BATTLE
Who's that photograph of? He doesn't look Japanese.
He is George Thurston. He was a principal architect in my original construction.
Oh? I didn't know that. He certainly did a good job with you.
Arigatō, Kanchou. Although many of my features are later modifications, he set the groundwork for it all.
But his name... isn't it British?
It is. We were allies back in the last war.
Ah yes, that's right. It's amazing how these sorts of alliances can change.
Indeed. And now we are all allied once more, to a degree, against the Funayūrei.
Makes you wonder how things might change in the future, doesn't it?
It does, it does...

Fields.MenuText: That explains why you seem to like British tea so much.
The politics of nations may change, but the bonds of individuals can endure.
Right now, we should focus on the present.

Fields.DialogueText: I like Japanese tea as well, but the English kind reminds me of my maker.
Truly. Let us put our faith in the endurance of such friendships and memories.
Right. The warrior must keep their mind on the ongoing battle before contemplating future possibilities.
Anyway, the memories still remain. I'm sure your architect still fondly remembers giving you your form, just as you remember him.
Arigatō, Kanchou. And, also...
Yes?
I hope we can continue our camaraderie after this war ends.
Me, too.
*ALARM*
There's the enemy. Let's show them the vision behind your construction, shall we?
@BATTLE
How do the waters look out there, Kanchou?
They look pretty calm at the moment. Actually, I was thinking of taking a dip.
That sounds like a good idea. You could use this to strengthen your swimming skills.
Always thinking of training, aren't you? So why not come along for the dive?
What? But... I'm not sure.
Why not? It would be fun.
I am just uneasy about exposing myself like that. And I am not very experienced with swimming. Sailing, yes, but not swimming.

Fields.MenuText: You're already used to traveling light without armor.
If you are afraid of this, you should work to overcome your fear.
It's okay if you don't want to. I just thought this would be fun for the two of us.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. I like to be agile, after all – and what is water but yet another means for travel?
You're right. I must not allow myself to pull back from challenges when I know in my heart, that I can overcome them.
That's true... it would be a lot of fun, wouldn't it? Especially since it would be with you...
All right, here I come!
Nice splash. Having fun?
I sure am! This makes me wonder if I can achieve my dream of the great depths.
What sort of dream are you talking about?
*ALARM*
I can tell you another time. Right now, we need to get back on deck. It is time to send the Funayūrei down for a permanent dive.
@BATTLE
Hello, Hiei... Um, what's with the baseball outfit I saw you wearing before?
What, were there smudges on it? I don't really have the time to worry about those things.
No, I was just surprised to see you dressed like that. I didn't know you even liked baseball.
It isn't the most popular in Japan yet, but it is growing. And I was at Palau when we first introduced it to the natives.
That's neat. What makes you so interested in it, though?
Well, for starters, it makes a handy weapon, I've learned. Even so, I'm still trying to figure out how to copy the trick of hitting projectiles back at the enemy.
It figures that's what you'd say.
But also, I think that it embodies Japan's patriotic spirit, and encourages participants to become all-purpose warriors.
How so? It's not like you can apply it to war.
But the overall principle – being hitters, and runners, and catchers – encourages individuals to become well-rounded. And that is essential in true fighters.
I guess that's one way to look at it. Plus, it's something fun you can do with people, right?
That, too.

Fields.MenuText: If it's played across the world, I'm not sure it can be called a Japanese sport.
Maybe we can organize a baseball game sometime.
You find inspiration from a lot of different things, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, but it nevertheless invigorates national spirit – including Japan's.
That would be an excellent exercise for us all. I will see to it.
That is what I try my best to do. All ways in the world, including the path of the samurai, are interlinked, such that each reinforces the other.
I have to say, though, you looked pretty cute in that attire.
That is... embarrassing for a warrior's pride, you know.
Sorry. But anyway, I like it.
You do?
*ALARM*
I guess we'll have to see if we can apply your baseball strategies to strike out these latest opponents.
@BATTLE
What are you looking at there, Hiei?
Just some old photographs I took on tour in the past.
That's neat. Mind if I take a look? I'm interested to see all of the places you've been.
Well... can you keep a secret? Please?
Of course. But I don't see why you should be embarrassed about these photos. They are beautiful! I especially like this one with the seaside cliff.
That's actually the one I'm worried about. You see, that area is part of the designated zone for the military operations at Sasebo.
Ah. And I take it they didn't want trespassers in that territory, right?
Exactly. More to the point, we are not to take photographs of that area, lest we inadvertently share naval secrets.
Then why did you take – and keep – the picture? Out of curiosity? You're usually one to follow protocol.
I... just really liked the natural environments there, and I wanted to keep those memories even after I left.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they will make it into a park someday.
I'm sure they would be understanding of you taking a couple of minor liberties.
It's okay. We all have little hobbies we enjoy.

Fields.DialogueText: That would be really nice. If so, we should go explore it together. I know some good spots for meditation.
Perhaps, but a couple of small faults can become devastating weaknesses. And I am ashamed that I broke my code.
Arigatō. Yours is an understanding soul, Kanchou.
Have you considered taking more photos in the present?
That sounds good. With your permission, of course.
You don't need to ask. Though I'd like to see the new ones when you've got them developed.
Sure.
*ALARM*
Maybe someone can get some shots of when we send these latest goons down to the sea floor.
@BATTLE
You don't have to feel bad about it. It's not wrong to enjoy things you like now and then.
Hey, no problem. I'm glad I can be here to support you.
What's below the surface that's got you so interested, Hiei?
I think I saw a few pieces of coral way down there.
Well, your eyes are better than mine. You must have the eyesight of a hawk!
That is common among Belles in general. I have just tried to strengthen mine as part of my training as a warrior.
Anyway, though, coral is pretty neat, huh?
It really is. Some of the islands I visited after the first war were built on the remains of ancient cities of coral, likely old palaces by the dragon kings.
I just hope we didn't damage any of it passing over.
Don't worry. I think it was down far enough to be safe. Still, I worry. The latest ones seem so fragile, as with all young life. Will any of them last long enough to become legends?

Fields.MenuText: We will need to be more considerate of their needs, then.
I think the issue is that not many people see them as alive.
Such a shame, given their beauty.

Fields.DialogueText: Agreed, we must take better care of nature's wonders. Such is our duty to the kami who gave us a world to call home.
That is a foolish assumption for people to make. Everything in this world has a spirit, so they should not disregard their fellow neighbors like that.
I know. All things are to perish in time, but it is cruel when the arrogance of mortals hurts the lives of others.
Well, let's try to do what we can.
As always, I will fight on as a warrior.
*ALARM*
We'd better not let them damage the coral!
@BATTLE
Okay, Hiei, what's next for our training? Meditation, or are we going to work on fighting again?
Both, actually.
Both? They seem kind of like opposites, actually.
Not so. To truly reach your potential as a fighter, you must be calm even in the midst of combat. Meditation helps with that, but we need to bridge the gap.
Okay, but how?
Simple. Do you remember how you usually meditate, and how to get your mind into such a state?
Well, yeah.
In that case, I want you to attempt to bring yourself to that mindset again, only this time it will be as you are fending me off with a sword. If I hit you, you will have to start over.
That sounds kind of hard.
We have come a long way from the beginning. It is only natural to increase the challenge to suit your newfound strengths.

Fields.MenuText: It will be kind of hard to concentrate and dodge things at the same time.
I don't think it can be done. It's like patting your head and rubbing your tummy simultaneously.
I'll do my best to overcome this new challenge.

Fields.DialogueText: It won't be that difficult. Look at me! I can do a lot of things all at once.
I can.
That is all I can ask of you, Kanchou. But know that I have full faith in you for this ordeal.
Okay, I'll – watch it! I'm still getting ready!
There is no waiting period in a real battle. You have to react as soon as you hear the first cries.
*ALARM*
And there's one now. Mind if we call this off for now?
Actually, let's see if you can apply the meditation technique while handling the battle.
Easier said than done...
@BATTLE
I think that it is partially because you are a living ship.
Semantics.
You can meditate and fight at the same time?
I was talking about patting your head and rubbing your stomach. It is quite easy once you get the hang of it.
Thanks, Hiei.
That's an interesting demon, I mean yokai, that you have there. Did you make it out of wood all by yourself?
Yes. I thought it would be good to make a kappa figure for good luck.
Interesting. They're the type that like cucumbers, right?
They are. I see you have been checking out my books on them?
A little. I have to say, you did a really good job with the carving. Everything looks so smooth and lifelike.
It was nothing significant. I simply applied my finesse as a swordfighter to the method of carving, cutting only what needed to be cut away and nothing more.

Fields.MenuText: Planning to make any more of them?
It might be good to give it some more color with paints.
What do you plan to use it for?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure about that. It would be rather wasteful using all that wood.
And ruin the natural feel of the wood? Never!
A spiritual guard for the deck, I was thinking.
You seem to have an interest in monsters, you know.
I would not call them monsters. They all have vital roles in the physical and spiritual realms.
Including the Morganas?
We'll have to wait and see about that.
*ALARM*
Let's just hope that your lucky statue gives us the edge we need right now.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I was thinking that we could attempt a special sort of training, a more... spiritual one.
What sort of training? More meditation?
Not quite. Rather... a test of courage.
Like a dare or something?
More like a ghost story. Or rather, a bunch of ghost stories.
I'm not sure I like the sound of that.
It is called Hyaku Monogatari. One hundred candles, one hundred stories. After we tell a story, we blow out a candle. If all of the candles are blown out, something strange will happen.
I take it these aren't cute and friendly stories either.
Of course not. That would ruin the whole point of the challenge. As each tale of a ghost or monster is told, the spirits of the world take a closer and closer peek.
In that case, I'm not sure if it is a good idea for us to do that.
But I was looking forward to it...

Fields.MenuText: I'm worried this could attract a lot of a different sort of monster.
That kind of sounds like we're tempting fate.
Has anyone ever reached 100 stories?

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. I didn't think of that. On the other hand, we could use the opportunity to lure them all right to us.
I know, and I regret that I am taking such risks. But if I cannot even face the darkness above the surface, how will I ever be able to face the shadows beneath?
No one has, but that is generally because they are too afraid to take the final step.
I'll think about it, okay?
Just let me know if you decide to do it with me, please?
Well, in any case, Hiei, I'm glad you're being adventurous. Even if I sometimes regret it.
*ALARM*
Plus, why do we need more monsters when we have plenty to deal with already?
They may seem large in numbers, but they will fall soon enough!
@BATTLE
Always eager for a fight, aren't you?
And pragmatic. Every battle brings us closer to victory, or closer to defeat.
What are you talking about?
Simply a little dream I have, one that will push me to my limits.
Whereas you welcome the challenge.
Exactly!
Kanchou, could you help me, please? My case full of past wages broke open, and the money scattered all over my room.
Sure, Hiei. I have to say, you certainly have a lot of money.
Well, I am not interested in material things, but that also means that I'm unlikely to spend much of it.
That makes sense. Say, that's an interesting tower on this one bill. What is it?
Good eye! That is the Hakko Ichu Monument in Miyazaki. I actually got to see it and pay homage there when escorting the emperor.
Neat! So it has some spiritual significance or something?
In a fashion. "Hakko ichu" was a saying by the founder of Japan. "Eight crown cords, one roof." Thus the Tower of the Emperor symbolizes how he will bring new peace to the world.
That's not the impression that a lot of people are getting.
That is because many have interpreted it to mean we should expand our vision for the future by force. Then again, given how stubborn people can be, that may be the only option.

Fields.MenuText: I recall a similar ambition amongst the people of Babel.
A lot of people have dreams like that, only they have different ideas on how to change the world.
Is it really just to force other people into your fold?

Fields.DialogueText: I remember hearing that from some of the Christians in Sasebo. But in Babel they were materialists, focusing on the tower alone. For us, the tower is a symbol for our larger dream.
Of course, but that is why we need to absorb them, so Japan can reach its true potential. Once all the world has connected its separate pieces together, enlightenment will come at last.
Think of it another way. If you saw people who could reach a better way of life but don't, wouldn't you want to help them reach that potential?
To be honest, I prefer to see the phrase as highlighting how the imperial moral guidance is disseminated to the world, and for us to find acceptance and respect in the world.
But not everyone agrees with you.
No, they do not. Even so, I have hope that, once the war is over, the tower can symbolize peace and true prosperity of the heart.
*ALARM*
Until then, we'll have to work to build our bonds out here and fight against those that would break them.
For the Emperor! For the eightfold path of our home!
@BATTLE
I somehow think you're missing the point.
Maybe...
Hey, Hiei. Do you want to do some training?
Actually, this time I want to teach you something special, something of my own work.
You came up with your own special martial arts move?
Well, I developed it, but I got the inspiration from something I witnessed in life.
So come on. Let's see what this technique is.
All right. I call this the spider's strike. You focus on fighting with all of your appendages, no matter what angle you are at. See?
Whoa, that's amazing. But how did you come up with the concept?
Some of the navy boys took up spider fighting after seeing the festival in Kagoshima. I saw how the arachnids fought, and I realized that it could be applied to our own fighting styles.

Fields.MenuText: That kind of fighting is kind of brutal – for us as spectators, I mean.
I think that your greatest gift is how you can find new meaning in everything.
I wonder if there are many spiders on board, actually.

Fields.DialogueText: That is sadly the case. But such is the nature of this world. Rather than seek enlightenment, most people instead invent ways to descend into darkness.
Arigatō, Kanchou. I try really hard to keep that outlook every day.
There probably are. They are hardy little creatures. In fact, perhaps I might start raising some.
Now, then, let us begin with the training.
Say, Hiei, have you figured out the specifics of the technique?
Not yet, I'm afraid. That comes with practice with others.
Then why haven't you tried it before?
Because... I wanted to share it with someone I can really trust.
*ALARM*
Hiei... that's really nice of you. Maybe we can get some practice in while handling these yokai.
@BATTLE
I know. That's part of why I like to learn things from you.
What?!
Oh, not to fight, but I think I would enjoy their company.
Just make sure they aren't venomous. Just because they can't hurt you doesn't mean they can't hurt me or others.
Hey, Hiei? I have... a little something I wanted to give you.
I appreciate the thought, Kanchou, but you know that I consider possessions to be a burden in the ascent to enlightenment. I will have to respectfully decline.
Just hold off on your decision until you see what I have, okay? Ta-daa!
Oh my. This is...
Yep, a set of giant chopsticks, made out of iron. When I saw them, I thought you would love to have it.
You're right, it is quite beautiful. Actually, though, I wonder if it could be used as a weapon.
A weapon?
Exactly. After all, a famous swordsman once killed a mosquito with his chopsticks.
Huh? You samurai have a lot of quirks, don't you?
Whatever do you mean?

Fields.MenuText: If you killed a mosquito with your chopsticks, though, wouldn't that make it unclean to eat? I don't think he could have done that.
How do you think you would fight with them?
I just hoped that you would like them. I want to make you happy.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. Such is the conundrum of such a thing: whether to dirty it through use, or dishonor its purpose through neglect.
There must be a way to strike. Perhaps stabbing, or used as pincers.
They do, Kanchou!
If you don't want them, I won't be able to use them myself... so I will just have to dispose of them.
It would be a waste to destroy such a work of art and design! I will keep the pair.
I thought you would say that.
And Kanchou... Arigatō. For doing this for me.
You're welcome, Hiei. I'm glad you like it.
*ALARM*
To return the favor, how about you give me a hand against these Morganas?
Of course I will!
@BATTLE
I meant that as a joke, not as a philosophy topic...
What are you reading?
The works of Miyamoto Musashi.
Ah, the Book of Five Rings, right? That makes sense. It has a lot of material up your alley.
Exactly. I look up to him as a model of a warrior. Though I do not always agree with his suggestions...
What do you mean?
This one section emphasizes that warriors fight for fame. But... fame is what I am against, as it draws me away from a path of humility and righteousness.
Well, it's only a part of the overall teachings, right? It should not make a significant difference in your own endeavors.
Still, the code of the warrior is at the heart of my existence. I don't know how to get past this contradiction.

Fields.MenuText: Lots of things on the way of Buddhism seem contradictory at first, don't they? But there's a greater riddle beneath the surface.
If I recall, that part of the book also highlights bringing fame to your lord, or nation.
Don't let these issues trouble you. Just focus on fighting on, as a true samurai.

Fields.DialogueText: Like a koan. That is a good comparison, Kanchou. I am grateful for your wisdom.
You're right, but that makes me wonder if I am hurting my homeland by giving them too much pride in their power.
You're right. I cannot sacrifice my humility, but neither should I doubt myself. As always, I will find my answers through actions on the battlefield.
Anyway, I know that it won't matter in the end.
What do you mean?
It just means that I know you will overcome whatever troubles you in the end. That is the kind of person you are, the person I aspire to be like.
I appreciate you putting your faith in me, Kanchou. Somehow, despite so many people praising me, this simple statement from you has greater power on me.
*ALARM*
For now, let's just continue to do as we are doing: seek a path as warriors who will save this world from its sorrows.
Yes. Surely we will surpass all the darkness and find new light in the world.
@BATTLE
It was just a little something I thought of.
Nevertheless, you are working your own way to enlightenment. I am so happy for you.
Sometimes things can't be helped when we give assistance. For every action, there are consequences, both good and bad.
Why so introspective, Hiei? You are staring out at the sea to no end. Do you see something in the sky?
No. Rather, I am trying to see beneath the waters.
What do you mean?
It is a secret wish of mine, but I had a dream after we sailed to the Mariana Islands. There is an abyss in those seas that they say is deeper than the highest mountain on land.
That's incredible.
Indeed. And I wondered, what would it be like to travel to those depths, to shed a light into that darkness?
So that's what you meant when we went swimming a while back.
That's right, and with the hundred stories. After all, surely such a place will house fearsome yokai forgotten by much of the world.
Can it be done, though? It seems like it would be a difficult journey. Even if you sunk yourself, I could not be sure you would reach that place.
Do not worry. I do not believe it is worth expending your life for. But I still wish to challenge myself, and this certain trial calls to me.

Fields.MenuText: I hear that there are also great mountain ranges under the oceans.
Perhaps the true way to access the sea's secrets is through the spiritual.
Given how you are built for water, you might have more luck with this than in traveling to your mountain.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, and that excites me even more. So many things we could see down there.
Yes, that is what I am thinking. After all, many heroes have traveled to dragon palaces and other places under the sea. Surely with enough true faith, such things are possible?
Exactly. I still want to see my namesake as well, but this will be a good first step.
Well, I am positive that you can achieve your wish, Hiei. So why don't we do some dive training to get you prepared for that?
That sounds great. I am glad I have your support, Kanchou.
Happy to give it. I'm interested in seeing you succeed, too.
*ALARM*
Besides, after dealing with Morganas – including ones that can swim below us – a little dive seems like a piece of cake.
@BATTLE
We?
Of course. I wouldn't want you to miss out on the experience.
And we have evidence that such magic may in fact be a true part of this world.
Funny how diving into the deepest trench is easier than walking to a mountain on land.
Hang in there, everyone. We've run into more resistance than usual, but we're going to make it through. Believe in it. Look out!
Ah, I'm burning. How disappointing! My guard was down.
Don't worry, Hiei! I'll help put out the fires.
Stay back! You might get hurt.
But you're getting hurt, right now!
Such is the burden I carry. But the least I can do is shoulder it so that those I care about don't have to suffer.
Hiei...
So get to safety, please. The others will need you in the coming battle.

Fields.MenuText: Like you said, the flames are a test of our strength, right? So let me prove my strength to stand beside you.
Things are only hopeless if you stand on your own, Hiei. Let me and others even the weight.
I accept that you are willing to risk your life to help us. So please, accept that I will do the same for you.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou... You've grown so strong.
All right, you are correct. As a team, we become much stronger than as individual blades.
But... what if you cannot meet the coming dangers?
I just wanted to be strong, like Mount Hiei. Even if I burn, my spirit can endure as an inspiration to others.
Save that until you actually die. Until then, I'll do everything I can to keep you alive, Hiei.
Arigatō. I owe you my life, and I will hold that debt seriously.
Just believe in yourself more. And in your faith. From the looks of this rain, they want us to win, too.
We should never give up.
Then let's finish this! The fire's been dealt with, so there's nothing left but the Morganas themselves.
@BATTLE
Well, I learned from the best, didn't I?
That's a risk I'll have to take. Because if I let you do all this alone when I could have done something, I wouldn't forgive myself.
Well, Hiei, your forest seems to be flourishing in spite of the conditions out here.
Arigatō. But it is simply the virtue of the plants' spirits after I showed my love and dedication to them.
Even trees have spirits, you think?
Of course! That is why they have found the will to live on and join us on our quest throughout the world.
In that case, I wonder if we can recruit any of them into the fleet?
Very funny. Trees can live a long time, so we'll just have to be patient and see if they choose to speak to us at some point.
Given everything that's happened so far, I'm not sure if I can take it as a joke anymore.
Anyway, do you wish to sit down in the shade with me?
Sure, if that's okay with you. I know that you usually like to focus on your work.
I would like to spend some time with you here. We can call it meditation. Besides, I think that the trees would be happy for people to put their shade to good use.
I'll take you up on the offer. It's going to get our uniforms a little messy, but I already know that that isn't very important to you.
It is our actions, not appearances or thoughts, that count in the end.
Pardon?
Never mind, just relax. Thank you again for letting me grow these environments on board.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if we could climb up one of the trees.
This is a good place to connect with nature.
I'm happy that you seem to have found joy in life in general.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like a good adventure. Just be careful not to break any of the branches.
It is, isn't it? I was a little worried at first, given its artificial nature, but it has managed to find its own identity as a forest.
I have. My role as a soldier remains a core piece of my life, but I also have found other things to give myself purpose. And I hope that we can find even more.
*ALARM*
Well, duty calls. Ready, Hiei?
You don't need to ask. Here I come!
@BATTLE
In that case, should we name this the "Hiei Forest"? Or maybe the "Samurai Woods" if your mountain already claims the title.
He-he! That's actually a good idea.
All right, Hiei, why don't we do some serious thinking about your trench dive plan?
Excellent idea, Kanchou. But... you're really going to help me with this? It is one of my more farfetched dreams, after all.
No sweat. I believe you can do it. We just need to work to find a way for it to happen.
You're right. So let's get started. I think that the key piece to victory is dedicated training, but first we need to determine what sort of regimen to use.
Actually, I think the biggest hurdle is going to be finding a way for you to go down there to begin with.
I think I will find the answer through spiritual meditation.
Still, you're going to need to get authorization for the expedition, so you should have a reasonable argument that they will accept.
That is a valid point. Plus, just because I have faith does not mean I should be lazy and leave things up to chance. A true warrior must be ready for anything.
So, what are your thoughts on how to make this work?
To be honest, I'm not actually sure yet.
You aren't?
Hey, I'm just a soldier, not a diver. Actually, I was hoping you might have an idea on what to do.
I'm not a professional at that myself, but I'll see what I can do.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps we can work to modify you into a part-time submarine.
We need to figure out the timing for the return to the surface.
Research of water yokai could prove invaluable.

Fields.DialogueText: That would require significant technological advances, Kanchou. Perhaps that day will come, but I think it is a long way off.
You mean for the "bends"? I agree, that is something I will need to determine through careful meditation. I think there is a metaphor for life in such a process, after all.
Going for the spiritual route, then? That's a good thought. One way to start might be with the Funayūrei. They are one breed we get to observe all the time.
Sorry I couldn't be more help.
Hey, it's a start, right? We'll just have to keep working on it.
*ALARM*
Still, between this and handling the Morganas, we're going to have our hands full.
@BATTLE
How are things going, Hiei?
Rather smoothly for now. I'm just keeping to my station for the patrol.
You're not bored or anything?
You know I'm not. Though I admit, this makes me a little nostalgic.
Remembering old patrol days?
Yes, when my teammates and I patrolled the seas between Japan and the Western lands back in the last war. Those were great times.
I take it you got along well with them.
I admired their spirit, especially Kongou's. But our duties took us in different directions. Such is the way of life, with endless meetings and partings.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if that will happen to us one day.
I'm sure they still think of you, too.
Just because people part does not necessarily mean they will never meet again.

Fields.DialogueText: I think about that as well. But no matter where life takes us, our bonds will endure.
I continue to keep them close in my heart. Such bonds endure beyond memory and death, after all.
Exactly. What matters is holding faith to the promise of friendship and... other bonds.
Well, keep up the good work out here.
I will. But I doubt that the peace will last for much longer.
Come on, where's that optimistic faith of yours?
*ALARM*
As I said, we need to be ready, as the Funayūrei give us no respite.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, could you please come in here for a moment?
Sure, Hiei. What do you need?
I have something to return the favor of the chopsticks you gave me.
I told you, you don't need to repay me.
Even so, I was already intending to give you this, as a testament to your rise as a warrior.
Wait, you mean...? A sword?!
Correct. It is time that you wield a weapon that belongs directly to you.
Wow! And you made this all by yourself?
I wasn't too humble. I got a few other Kami to offer their guidance to me. But I managed the actual forging on my own.
I'm so proud of you, managing to do that on your first time.
I'm happy as well. I have always felt an affinity to fire, and this has helped me further develop my connection to the element, and to my heart as a soldier.
Water and fire, huh? Both of those are part of the process, so it makes sense that you are already a pro at it.
You are giving me too much credit again! But anyway, what do you wish to name your sword?

Fields.MenuText: Hiei's Partner.
Fire's Heart.
Sea Wanderer.

Fields.DialogueText: Rather forward of you, Kanchou!
An excellent name. But make sure that you fuel your own fire with ideals from your soul, not mine. Only then will it sparkle most wonderfully.
A fitting name for the one who leads us on our odyssey throughout the world. I am grateful for the opportunity to serve under you, Kanchou.
Thank you, Hiei.
You are welcome, Kanchou. Now, remember, you must treat your weapon with great respect and love. Through such bonds, miracles can be wrought on the battlefield.
*ALARM*
Then let's use our own ties to overcome this latest challenge.
@BATTLE
I'm sorry. I can choose another name if you like...
You've chosen a name for your weapon, so you must not go back on your word...
Yes, sensei.
And I'm grateful that you have been here, helping me along the way.
Oh, Kanchou! I have a surprise for you!
More food for me, Hiei? You shouldn't have!
I just wanted to make sure that the food wouldn't go to waste. We caught a surplus of fish a while back, so I salted the ones left over.
And then you baked them with corn cakes, I see.
It's a local recipe they make in Dairen. Some of the sailors enjoyed it when we were stationed there.
Well, it certainly looks tasty. Did you have any trouble making it?
Not at all. Though that somehow worries me.
How so?
I only have limited capacity to focus on different things. By doing this, have I staggered my meditations and fighting skills?

Fields.MenuText: Don't put limits on what you think you can and cannot do.
If you're happy with yourself, does it really matter?
I think what you really seem to care about is helping others, which you are still doing.

Fields.DialogueText: I should have faith that I can branch out along different paths without sacrificing one or the other?
I should not worry, since it is a hindrance to enlightenment. Personally, though, I'm not sure.
Good point. I focus primarily on honing my fighting skills since that is how I can best assist, but if I develop skills that allow me to serve in another way, I can work with that as well.
What do you think of the salted fish?
Great! I love the food you make, Hiei. Actually, I might like to make some for you sometime, to return the favor.
*ALARM*
Rest time is over. The war must continue.
@BATTLE
Hi, Hiei, how are –?
Shhh! I need to concentrate!
Oh, I'm sorry. Is that some sort of glass there?
It is. I am trying to make some studio glass in the traditional style of Otaru.
That's neat. I think you will be able to do that pretty easily, since you've already mastered forging swords. That's got to be harder than this.
Don't be so sure. Everything can be challenging depending on your perspective. I am well versed in handling weapons, but I have more difficulty with fragile things like glass.
Any luck so far?
Sort of. I'm getting there, but it's still proving difficult.

Fields.MenuText: Just try to focus on understanding the craft.
Glass is sharp enough to constitute a weapon in its own right.
Think of it like flowing through the waves of the sea.

Fields.DialogueText: Right! Like everything, I must be patient and diligent in my studies.
That's an interesting point. Yes... this is like tempering a weapon to make it safer. I can work with that.
I get it. My technique should be like water carving into malleable sand on the shoreline.
Well, I think this is as good as it will get until it cools down.
I think it's coming along nicely, by the looks of it. Say, what were you planning to use it for?
Um...
*ALARM*
Come on! We had best shatter this formation before they can dent our forces.
@BATTLE
That's an interesting scroll, Hiei. Who are the individuals on it?
The Eight Immortals of Chinese mythology. I received the artwork as a gift when I was at Chefoo. They left from there on their journey to find immortality.
Well, they certainly look like an interesting band of individuals.
They are. Many of China's great martial arts stemmed from their teachings, and I am convinced that they influenced the deities who immigrated from there to Japan.
They definitely sound like people you admire.
Well, I admire their skills. Their outlook on life is another matter entirely.
What do you mean?
I just think that they made a mistake seeking out immortality. They have reached a great understanding of life, but without mortality, how can they truly find enlightenment?
Well, it is natural for us to want to live forever, right?
To live, yes, but how? If you decide that living is more important than the actual things you do when alive, at some point you will become lost.
What about you, then?
Me? My life could last for a long time, or be cut short like a wick. Either way, I would rather appreciate the time I have than give up my future in the world beyond just to live longer.

Fields.MenuText: But I thought that Kami and other gods are immortal as well?
Aren't you scared of what might – or might not – be waiting for you after death?
Just because they have a different view of things doesn't necessarily mean that they are wrong – just different.

Fields.DialogueText: We often have longer lifespans and better health, true, but we can still die. A forest spirit depends on its home's state, and even the greatest of gods have been sent to Yami.
I am. But I must stay strong and believe that there will surely be an answer to what we are all asking in that place. Until then, though, I will embrace life to the fullest.
You may be right, and I respect their choice. Even so, I will stick to my own principles to the very end.
Well, I hope we can be together as long as possible.
Of course we will, Kanchou. After all, such is the destiny we both have faith in, right?
Yes, you're right.
*ALARM*
Sometimes I wonder if the Morganas are immortal, though.
Don't give up. Everything comes to an end one way or another.
@BATTLE
Hey, Kanchou! I looked at the chart, and we are passing over a set of underwater landmarks at this very moment.
That's pretty interesting, Hiei. Too bad we won't be able to see them.
Maybe we can. That is why I wanted to talk to you.
What do you mean?
I worked with a friend on board, and we made a small, remote probe that should be able to travel down there – and send footage up.
That's amazing, Hiei!
Well, I did what I could, but the majority was done by my friend.
Even so, this is a great accomplishment for you. So, I assume you want to send it down there, right?
If that is all right with you.
Of course! Just as long as I can watch, too.
I was hoping you would. Okay, it's launched! What do you think of the footage?

Fields.MenuText: A little blurry.
It seems like another world.
There are a lot of different things down there.

Fields.DialogueText: Such is the case with everything. We begin by seeing as if through a mist, but surely over time we will see more and more of the world.
This plane of reality is like a sea of foam, with countless bubbles floating on their own. Yet when we look closer, they all give form to the world's beauty.
Such is the diversity of life. Life came from the mighty seas, so it is natural for the greatest kingdoms to be beneath the waters.
Thank you for sharing this with me, Hiei.
You're welcome, Kanchou. Oh! It must have broken, somehow.
I'm sorry, Hiei.
It's okay. I am simply happy that I managed to get a glimpse into that world. Now I am more determined than ever to travel there myself.
Still, I wonder what damaged the machine. Everything looked like it was going fine...
*ALARM*
I think I found the answer to that.
@BATTLE
Kanchou... could we talk, please?
Sure, Hiei. Want to walk while we're at it? That always gets you in a good mood.
That would be lovely, thank you.
So, what is it you wanted to talk about?
We have both progressed greatly, haven't we? Head over to those trees – there's something I need to pick up.
Sure thing, Hiei. I've been grateful to learn so much from you.
And I have appreciated learning more about life, in all aspects, from you.
I only wanted to encourage you to be yourself. That person is beautiful to me in so many ways.
Even as I search for enlightenment, I know I want to stay in this world with you as long as I can.
Hiei...
Kanchou, you have taken a place in my heart - and it brings me peace.
Whatever the future holds, we have forged a bond. Maybe one that is stronger than with your previous crew mates that you remember so fondly?
Kanchou, it is a deeper bond. I do not want to name it... I fear the word most people would use would...
Sit with me, in the shade of the trees, would you? We can look at the skies together for a quiet moment.

Fields.MenuText: I understand, Hiei. I feel it, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Morganas, Hiei! Let's show them our warrior spirit.
Of cours, Kanchou. Our steel is ready.
@BATTLE
I would love to, Hiei.

Fields.MenuText: You mean "love"?

Fields.DialogueText: Call it what you will, Kanchou. I just know that it stirs in me.
That makes me glad, Kanchou.
